title: 111_hr3115
content: The Small Business Health Care Affordability Act of 2009, also known as the "Small Employers Business Credit for Providing Employee Health Insurance," introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide employee health insurance coverage by small employers. The Small Business Health Care Affordability Act of 2009 introduces a new section in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for eligible small employers to receive a health insurance credit based on the amount paid for qualified health insurance for employees. The credit is subject to annual and monthly limitations based on the amounts paid for employee coverage. The Small Business Health Care Affordability Act of 2009 allows eligible small employers to receive a health insurance credit based on the amount paid for qualified health insurance for employees. The credit is subject to annual and monthly limitations based on the amounts paid for employee coverage, with specific limits for different types of coverage. Eligible small employers are defined as those who employed an average of 50 or fewer employees in the preceding taxable years. The Small Business Health Care Affordability Act of 2009 provides a health insurance credit for eligible small employers based on the amount paid for qualified health insurance. The credit is determined by the average number of employees and whether the employer provided qualified health insurance in preceding years. The Small Business Health Care Affordability Act of 2009 offers a health insurance credit for eligible small employers based on the number of employees and provision of qualified health insurance in preceding years. Special rules apply for controlled groups and predecessors of employers. The term 'coverage month' is defined for individuals. The term 'coverage month' is defined for individuals based on their health insurance coverage and premium payment by eligible small employers. It excludes months where individuals are already receiving benefits from Medicare, Medicaid, or SCHIP. The term 'coverage month' excludes months where individuals receive benefits under chapter 55 of title 10, are imprisoned, or are present in the United States for fewer than 183 days in a taxable year. The term 'qualified health insurance' refers to coverage under a group health plan that meets specific requirements, excluding certain types of insurance. The coverage must be provided in a State with adjusted community rating or rating bands. The coverage must be provided in a State with a community rating structure that does not permit rating on gender, health status, or claims experience. The coverage must also be provided under a plan that is at least an actuarial equivalent to the standard Blue Cross-Blue Shield plan offered under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. In a conforming amendment, paragraph (34) is modified by adding a new paragraph (36) for eligible small employers to receive a health insurance credit. The table of sections is also amended to reflect this change. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009. A new section allows for a refundable small business employee health premium credit for health insurance costs for small business employees. The new section allows eligible small business employees to claim a tax credit for qualified health insurance paid for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. The credit is limited to the total amount paid for insurance coverage during the taxable year. An individual qualifies as an eligible small business employee if they are enrolled in qualified health insurance provided by an eligible small employer. The section discusses the rules and coordination of the tax credit for qualified health insurance provided by eligible small employers. It includes provisions for coordination with medical expense deductions and deductions for health insurance costs of self-employed individuals. The taxpayer must choose between the tax credit under this section and section 35 for each month. The Secretary will create necessary regulations. Conforming amendments are made to related sections. The amendments made by this section regarding health insurance costs for small business employees will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009.
